courses.name: Introductory Chemistry
courses.description: Introductory course for students with no high school background in chemistry.  Covers fundamental principles of scientific measurement, stoichiometry, solutions, basic atomic structure, gases.  No credit if taken after CHEM 1100.

courses.name: Atoms and Molecules with Lab
courses.description: One-semester introduction for non-science majors to the basic concepts and important applications of chemistry. Satisfies A&S requirement for a laboratory science. No credit if taken after CHEM 1310.

courses.name: Atoms and Molecules with Laboratory - Honors
courses.description: One-semester introduction for non-science majors to the basic concepts and important applications of chemistry. Satisfies A&S requirement for a laboratory science. No credit if taken after CHEM 1310.

courses.name: College Chemistry I
courses.description: First of two-course sequence emphasizing principles and applications of modern chemical sciences.  Covers chemical nomenclature, stoichiometry, kinetic molecular theory, atomic structure, periodic properties, and molecular structure and bonding.  Satisfies laboratory science requirement. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.

courses.name: College Chemistry I - Honors
courses.description: First of a two-course sequence emphasizing principles and applications of modern chemical sciences. Covers chemical nomenclature, stoichiometry, kinetic molecular theory, atomic structure, periodic properties, and molecular structure and bonding. Satisfies laboratory science requirement. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100 or MATH 1120 or equivalent. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: College Chemistry II
courses.description: Continuation of CHEM 1320. Covers intermolecular forces, solutions, kinetics, acid-base chemistry, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, thermodynamics.  Satisfies requirement for a laboratory science.  May be taken concurrently with CHEM 2030 or CHEM 2100.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in CHEM 1320 or CHEM 1320H

courses.name: College Chemistry II- Honors
courses.description: Continuation of CHEM 1320H. Covers equilibria, kinetics, electrochemistry, nuclear chemistry, thermodynamics. Satisfies requirement for a laboratory science. May be taken concurrently with CHEM 2030 or CHEM 2100.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in  CHEM 1320 or CHEM 1320H. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Honors Intensive General Chemistry with Lab - Honors
courses.description: A one-semester, intensive introduction to chemistry for honors-eligible students that takes the place of CHEM 1320, CHEM 1330. Four lectures and one 3-hour lab period per week. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: honors eligibility, college algebra and one year of high school chemistry or instructor's consent

courses.name: Survey of Organic Chemistry
courses.description: One-semester introduction to structure and bonding, functional group chemistry, principles of reactivity, reaction mechanisms, the molecules of life.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C or better in CHEM 1320 or CHEM 1320H or equivalent. Recommended CHEM 1330, or CHEM 1330 concurrently

courses.name: Organic Chemistry I
courses.description: First course of a two-semester sequence. Structure and bonding; chemistry of hydrocarbons, alkyl halides, alcohols and ethers; reaction mechanisms; principles of reactivity and synthesis; IR and NMR spectroscopy.  Only 1 hour credit if taken after CHEM  2030 or equivalent.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or better in CHEM 1320 or equivalent or CHEM 1330 concurrently,

courses.name: Organic Chemistry II
courses.description: Continuation of CHEM 2100.  Aromatic hydrocarbons, carbonyls, amines; chemistry of carbanions; reactions of polar double bonds; nucleic acids, proteins, carbohydrates and fats.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or better in CHEM 2100 or equivalent, or departmental consent

courses.name: Organic Laboratory I
courses.description: Basic lab techniques, functional group manipulations, and short syntheses.  Pre-lab and post-lab writing assignments. 1 hour recitation,  3 hours lab per week.
courses.recommendation: Concurrent enrollment in CHEM 2110 or CHEM 2030.  No credit for students who have previous organic laboratory credit

courses.name: Organic Laboratory II
courses.description: Continuation of CHEM 2130.  Preparation and identification of organic compounds; application of instrumental techniques.  2 lab sessions, 1 recitation session per week.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or better in CHEM 2110 and CHEM 2130 or equivalent

courses.name: Honors Organic Chemistry I - Honors
courses.description: First course of a two-semester sequence. Similar to CHEM 2100 but with increased depth and breadth; emphasis on preparing science students for research and professional careers. 3 lectures, 1 discussion session per week.
courses.prerequisites: honors eligibility, grade of B or better in CHEM 1320 or equivalent

courses.name: Honors Organic Chemistry II with Lab - Honors
courses.description: Continuation of CHEM 2160H; includes laboratory. Content and structure similar to  CHEM 2110, but with increased depth and breadth.
courses.prerequisites: honors eligibility, grade of B or better in CHEM 2160H or instructor's permission

courses.name: Honors Organic Chemistry Laboratory - Honors
courses.description: Preparation and identification of organic compounds; multistep syntheses; application of instrumental techniques, including NMR, FTIR, MS and HPLC. 2 lab sessions, 1 discussion session per week.
courses.prerequisites: honors eligibility, grade of C or better in CHEM 2170H or equivalent

courses.name: Fundamentals of Inorganic Chemistry with Lab
courses.description: A systematic introduction with laboratory to inorganic and organometallic compounds, reactions, and periodic properties.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or better in CHEM 1330

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Chemistry
courses.description: A laboratory research project and/or preparation of compounds with a written final report. Cannot be substituted for other chemistry courses required for a B.S. or B.A. degree. No more than 6 hrs. total credit.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing, 2.75 GPA and/or instructor's consent

courses.name: Quantitative Methods of Analysis with Lab
courses.description: Principles and practice of quantitative analysis, including the basic principles of modern instrumental methods.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Physical Chemistry
courses.description: Survey of physical chemistry.  Satisfies physical chemistry prerequisite for BIOCHM 8430.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1700, a course in organic chemistry; PHYSCS 1210 and PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2175, or PHYSCS 2176 concurrently

courses.name: Physical Chemistry I
courses.description: Lecture only. Topics include the kinetic theory of gases, chemical kinetics, thermodynamics and chemical equilibrium.
courses.prerequisites: one semester organic chemistry and PHYSCS 2175, PHYSCS 2176 and MATH 2300, or MATH 2300 concurrently

courses.name: Physical Chemistry II
courses.description: Continuation of  CHEM 3310. Lecture only. Covers wave mechanics, bonding, molecular spectroscopy and statistical mechanics.

courses.name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C or better in  CHEM 3200; CHEM 3330 or CHEM 3330 concurrently

courses.name: Undergraduate Seminar in Chemistry
courses.description: Methods for locating and presenting chemical information, data analysis techniques, professional issues.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 1330 or CHEM 1500H; CHEM 2100 or CHEM 2160H

courses.name: Undergraduate Seminar in Chemistry - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Methods for locating and presenting chemical information, data analysis techniques, professional issues.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 1330 or CHEM 1500H; CHEM 2100 or CHEM 2160H

courses.name: Internship in Chemistry
courses.description: Cannot be substituted for other chemistry courses required for B.S. or B.A. degree.

courses.name: Service-Learning in Chemistry
courses.description: A service-learning community outreach program affording chemistry students with an opportunity to enhance their problem-solving skills. May be repeated once for credit. Satisfies no specific chemistry degree requirements, nor Arts and Science general education requirements. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Chemistry - General
courses.description: Organized study designed to broaden the knowledge base of students. Subjects on analytical, inorganic, organic and physical chemistry covered.

courses.name: Topics in Chemistry- Natural Science
courses.description: Organized study designed to broaden the knowledge base of students. Subjects on analytical, inorganic, organic and physical chemistry covered.

courses.name: Advanced Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: Advanced methods for the synthesis and characterization of organic, inorganic, and organometallic compounds.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 2400, CHEM 2140, or CHEM 2190H, CHEM 3200, CHEM 3330 (or CHEM 3330 corequisite)

courses.name: Problems in Chemistry
courses.description: Individual study under the direction of a faculty member that supplements regular course work.

courses.name: Intermediate Organic Chemistry
courses.description: Stresses synthetic organic chemistry at an intermediate level.
courses.prerequisites: at least one year organic chemistry

courses.name: Medicinal Chemistry
courses.description: Chemical mechanisms of drug action. Topics include drug metabolism and action, chemical toxicology and medicines, enzyme activity, and specific drug case studies.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 2110, or CHEM 2170H, CHEM 3300 or CHEM 3310 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Instrumental Methods of Analysis with Lab
courses.description: (cross-leveled with CHEM 7200). Chemical instrumentation methods including electrochemistry, spectroscopy, and advanced separations techniques.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 3200, a semester of physical chemistry

courses.name: Environmental Chemistry
courses.description: Surveys the chemistry of air and water environments; discusses the chemistry of waste treatment.
courses.prerequisites: 8 hours chemistry including organic and analytical

courses.name: Environmental-Toxicological Chemistry
courses.description: In-depth study of the chemical aspects of current issues dealing with environmental pollutants and toxic chemical substances.

courses.name: Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: (cross-leveled with CHEM 7400). Atomic and molecular structure, bonding, kinetics and mechanism, ligand field theory, coordination compounds, acids and bases.
courses.prerequisites: one semester Physical Chemistry, second semester concurrently

courses.name: Physics and Chemistry of Materials
courses.description: (same as NU_ENG 4319, PHYSCS 4190 and  BIOL_EN 4480; cross-leveled with CHEM 7490, NU_ENG 7319, PHYSCS 7190, BIOL_EN 7480). Undergraduate/graduate level course offered every spring semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures, laboratory demonstrations, two midterm and one final exam. Graduate students will submit a term paper.

courses.name: Introduction to Radiochemistry with Lab
courses.description: (same as NU_ENG 4391). Introduces application of radio-tracer techniques to chemical research.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 1330 or CHEM 1500H; and one semester of physical chemistry, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Chemistry Teaching Practicum
courses.description: Provides practical experience teaching introductory chemistry in discussion and laboratory settings.  For students pursuing dual degrees in chemistry and secondary education. For students pursuing simultaneous dual degrees in chemistry and secondary education. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Senior Research
courses.description: A laboratory research project with approved written goals and a final written report. It may be taken twice.

courses.name: Senior Honors Research I
courses.description: A laboratory research experience with a student-instructor prepared outline approved by the Honors Director, a final written report and a final oral presentation and examination.
courses.prerequisites: a 3.33 GPA, departmental consent, and approval of project outline. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Senior Honors Research II
courses.description: A laboratory research experience with a student-instructor prepared outline approved by the Honors Director, a final written report and a final oral presentation and examination.
courses.prerequisites: a 3.33 GPA, departmental consent, approval of project outline. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Seminar in Chemistry for Beginning Graduate Students
courses.description: Seminar in Chemistry for Beginning Graduate Students

courses.name: Instrumental Methods of Analysis with Lab
courses.description: (cross-leveled with CHEM 4200). Chemical instrumentation methods including electrochemistry, spectroscopy, and advanced separations techniques.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 3200, a semester of physical chemistry

courses.name: Intermediate Physical Chemistry
courses.description: Treatment of atomic and molecular, structure and spectroscopy based on quantum concepts. Designed to provide a broad base of knowledge in these fundamental areas to beginning graduate students in chemistry.

courses.name: Inorganic Chemistry
courses.description: (cross-leveled with CHEM 4400). Atomic and molecular structure, bonding, kinetics and mechanism, ligand field theory, coordination compounds, acids and bases.
courses.prerequisites: one semester Physical Chemistry, second semester concurrently

courses.name: Physics and Chemistry of Materials
courses.description: (same as NU_ENG 7319, PHYSCS 7190, BIOL_EN 7480; cross-leveled with CHEM 4490, NU_ENG 4319, PHYSCS 4190, BIOL_EN 4480). Undergraduate/graduate level course offered every winter semester for students from Physics, Chemistry, Engineering and Medical Departments and consists of lectures, laboratory demonstrations, two midterm and one final exam. Graduate students will submit a term paper.
courses.prerequisites: PHYSCS 2760 and CHEM 1320 or equivalent and instructor's consent

courses.name: Topics in Chemistry - Natural Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earned credit may vary from semester to semester. Repeatable upon consent of department.

courses.name: Introduction to X-ray Crystallography
courses.description: Designed for students in chemistry and related fields. Aimed at offering a practical understanding of single-crystal x-ray structural studies. Includes hands-on laboratory work (data collection and analysis).

courses.name: Non-Thesis Research in Chemistry
courses.description: Does not lead to dissertation.

courses.name: Topics in Chemistry
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earned credit may vary from semester to semester. Repeatable upon consent of department.

courses.name: Seminar in Chemistry
courses.description: Seminar in Chemistry

courses.name: Thesis/Dissertation (pre-candidacy) Research in Chemistry
courses.description: Research leading to thesis. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Physical Organic Chemistry I
courses.description: Bonding theory, physical methods, absorption spectroscopy, conformational analysis, mechanism of reactions.

courses.name: Physical Organic Chemistry II
courses.description: Case studies and methods for determining organic reaction mechanisms.

courses.name: Organic Reaction Mechanisms
courses.description: Organic reaction mechanisms are discussed within a framework of structure-reactivity relationships. Particular attention directed to the chemistry of reactive intermediates and the application of stereochemical and molecular orbital concepts.
courses.prerequisites: 1 year of Organic Chemistry and Physical Chemistry

courses.name: Organic Spectroscopy
courses.description: Structural analysis of organic compounds involving problem solving using modern NMR, IR, UV-VIS, MS CD/ORD and other spectroscopic techniques.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 3330 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.name: Applications of the Reactions of Organic Chemistry
Analytical Measurement
courses.description: Fundamental and applied aspects of scientific measurements. Topics include: Statistics, signal-to-noise, frequency analysis, sources of noise, digital and analog filtering, time vs. frequency domain measurements, Fourier transformation, sampling, convolution/deconvolution, autocorrelation and cross-correlation. Directed toward entering graduate students.

courses.name: Separations and Chromatography
courses.description: Classical and instrumental methods of separation: gas, paper, thin film, and column chromatography; ion exchange.

courses.name: Mass Spectrometry
courses.description: This course will cover various aspects of modern mass spectrometry.  Topics will include instrumentation, theory, uses and interfaces to mass spectrometry.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Analytical Spectroscopy
courses.description: Selected topics dealing with recent advances in analytical chemistry.

courses.name: Surface Analysis and Characterization
courses.description: Covers various aspects of modern methods of surface analysis and characterization.  Topics include instrumentation, theory, and data reduction methods.  Major sections include electron spectroscopy, microscopy, and vibrational spectroscopy as applied to surfaces.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Fluorescence Spectroscopy
courses.description: Advanced analytical chemistry course that explores the fundamental principles and uses of modern fluorescence spectroscopy in biology, materials science, chemistry, physics and engineering.  Special emphasis is placed on the methodologies used to obtain specific information about a particular chemical system.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Analytical Chemistry
courses.description: Continuation of CHEM 8250.

courses.name: Bioanalytical Chemistry
courses.description: This course is aimed at introducing students to the instrumental and theoretical principles by which biological molecules are measured in vivo and in vitro.  The course explores how protein, DNA and metabolite structures and quantities are determined in the laboratory with an emphasis on understanding historical methods up through cutting edge approaches in each field.   The theory of measurement techniques, separation techniques and related instrumentation are explored in the context of understanding the chemical equilibria that govern each instance.   Students will leave this course with a broad understanding for how many biological molecules are measured and what the limitations of various techniques may be.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nanochemistry
courses.description: Covers various aspects of nanochemistry.  Topics include synthesis and characterization of nonmaterial, nanotoxicity, and catalysis.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Physical Chemistry
courses.description: Advanced Physical Chemistry

courses.name: Quantum Chemistry
courses.description: Introduction to formal quantum mechanical theory, quantum measurement, simple model problems having exact solutions, angular momenta, approximation methods (perturbation theory, variation principle, WKB), and the structure of many-electron atoms.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 3330 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.name: Chemical Kinetics
courses.description: Factors affecting rates, orders and mechanisms of chemical reactions, with emphasis on current theories and experimental techniques.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 3330 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.name: Computational Chemistry
courses.description: Theory and application of modern computational techniques (molecular mechanics, ab initio and semiempirical molecular orbital methods) for predicting the structures, energies, and properties of molecules and molecular systems.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 3300 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Mechanics
courses.description: Principles of statistical mechanics and their application to chemical systems; ensemble theory; condensed phases.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 3330 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.name: Magnetic Resonance
courses.description: Basic principles of nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and electron spin resonance (ESR), nuclear spin relaxation, current experimental techniques and the application to studies of structures, dynamics and chemical analysis.
courses.prerequisites: One year of organic chemistry, CHEM 3300 or equivalent

courses.name: Inorganic Mechanisms
courses.description: Experimental stoichiometry and rate law determination. Isotopic applications. Methods and results of fast reaction studies. Basic known inorganic mechanisms. Experimental methods of establishing mechanisms of reaction.

courses.name: Chemistry of the Main Group Elements
courses.description: Descriptive inorganic chemistry of the main group elements. Textbook material extensively supplemented with information from the current chemical literature.

courses.name: Supramolecular Chemistry
courses.description: The basics of supramolecular chemistry will be covered, including host-guest complexes, reorganization, complementarily, thermodynamic interactions, self assembly and biochemical, molecular device and crystal engineering applications. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BS in Chemistry, Biochemistry or Chemical Engineering

courses.name: Coordination Chemistry and Reactivity
courses.description: The chemistry of the transition elements (d-block) and their reactivity will be discussed, including bonding, coordination numbers, oxidation states, and reactivity (kinetics).  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 4400 or equivalent; graduate standing in chemistry or instructor's consent

courses.name: Inorganic Structural Methods
courses.description: Chemical bonding, application of group theory, spectroscopy; diffraction as applied to structure determination; structural implications of dipole moment and magnetic susceptibility measurements.

courses.name: Organometallics
courses.description: Condensations effected by organometallics; dissolving metal reductions; sandwich compounds and related organotransition metal derivatives.

courses.name: Solid State Chemistry
courses.description: An introduction to the unique aspects of extended solids.  Crystal symmetry, group theory and their applications to crystallography.  Bonding and electronic structure theories of metals and semiconductors.  Cooperative magnetism and superconductivity.  Defects and ionic conductivity.  Preparative methods in solid state chemistry.

courses.name: Actinide Chemistry
courses.description: The course covers the inorganic and organometallic chemistry of the actinides.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Chemistry of Nanomaterials
courses.description: This course will cover several aspects of nanomaterials including synthesis and processing of small particles, as well as their characterization by crystallography, scanning tunneling microscopy magnetism, and other optical properties.  Also studied will be the application of quantum confinement to the electronic and optical properties of nanomaterials and the development of photonic materials.  The nanostructure of organic polymers, micelles, and the process of biomineralization to make organic-inorganic hybrid materials will also be discussed.

courses.name: Radiochemistry and Detection with Lab
courses.description: An introductory course in the applications of radionuclides in chemistry. Topics include radioactive decay, interactions of radiation with matter, radioactive tracers, and nuclear methods of analysis. Directed towards entering graduate students.

courses.name: Advanced Radiochemistry
courses.description: Reviews current advances in radiochemistry, hot atom chemistry, radiation chemistry, nuclear spectrometry.

courses.name: Nuclear Chemistry
courses.description: Designed for graduate students in chemistry and related fields. Studies nuclear reaction and nuclear properties.

courses.name: Radiopharmaceutical Chemistry
courses.description: The radiotracer concept, history of nuclear medicine, radionuclide production, organic and inorganic chemistry of radiopharmaceutical chemistry, and applications will be discussed.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: undergraduate organic and inorganic chemistry; graduate standing in chemistry or instructor's consent

courses.name: Biological Radiochemistry
courses.description: Covers the interaction of radiation on biological material  The effects of radiation overdose is discussed along with the use of radiation in therapy.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Post-candidacy Dissertation Research in Chemistry
courses.description: Research leading to Ph.D. dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.
